_header: The life so short the craft so long to learn
Note: The roundel inserted between stanzas 97-98 occurs only in MSS. Oxford, Bodleian Library Digby 181 (SC 1782), Oxford, St John’s College 57 and Cambridge UK, Cambridge University Library Gg.4.27 (Part 1a), and in Geoffrey Chaucer, Workes, Thynne, 1532 ; see 3815. For extract see 6722.
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, Parlement of Foules — 98 stanzas rhyme royal

BodArcSelB24.First Lines:
…Off a sage olde quhat for loue quhat for loreOn bokis red I
                    oft as I ȝou told…
BodArcSelB24.Last Lines:
…The lyf so schort the craft so long to lereTo full connyng I
                    can nocht cum suppose I rede all ȝere
BodArcSelB24.Note: Lacks lines 1-14; has a unique ending.
BodArcSelB24.Attributed Title:
Here endis the Parliament of foules Quod Galfride Chaucere (f.
                    152)
BodArcSelB24.Facsimiles:
Boffey,  Julia,  and  A. S. G. Edwards, eds.  
             Chaucer, Works. Bodleian Library MS Arch Selden B.24: Facsimile
                Edition.
         Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1995.
BodArcSelB24.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Supplementary Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor
                Poems.
             2 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st ser. 22, 59. London: Trübner, n.d.; repr. New York and London:
            Johnson, 1967.

Bod638.First Lines:
…Cometh al this new corne fro yere to yereAnd out of olde
                    bokys in good feyth…
Bod638.Last Lines:
…That I shall mete som thinge for to fareThe bet & thus to
                    rede I will not spare
Bod638.Attributed Title:
[The Parlement] Of ffowlys (f. 96, RT); Explicit tractatus de
                        congregacione volucra die Sancti Valentini (f. 110)
Bod638.Facsimiles:
Robinson,  Pamela. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Bodley 638: A Facsimile.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, and Woodbridge: Boydell and Brewer, 1982.

BodDig181.First Lines:
The life so short the crafte so longe to lerneThe assay so harde so
                    sharp the conqueryng…
BodDig181.Last Lines:
…That I shall mete some thyng for to fareThe bettir and thus
                    to rede I woll not spare
BodDig181.Attributed Title:
the parlement of ffowlis (f. 44), Explicit. Here endith the parlement of
                    ffowlis (at the end)

BodLauMis416.First Lines:
the lyf so short the craft so long to lerneTheassay so sharp so
                    hard þe conqueryng…
BodLauMis416.Last Lines:
…Thise versis of gold and blak ywretyn wereThe which I gan
                    Astonyed to be hold

BodTan346.First Lines:
The lif so short the craft so long to lerneThe assay so hard so

BodTan346.Last Lines:

                    rede I hyl not spare

OxfStJohn57.First Lines:
The lyff so short the crafft so long to lernThassay so sharpp so
                    hard the conqueryng…
OxfStJohn57.Last Lines:
…That I shall mete som thing for to fareThe bett and thus to
                    rede I woll nat spare Explicit

CULFf16.First Lines:
The lyfe so schorte the crafte so long to lerneThassaye so scharpe
                    so harde þe conquerygnThe dredfull Ioye allwey þat slydeth
                    ȝernAl this men I be loue þat my felygn…
CULFf16.Last Lines:
…That I shall meete some thyng for to fareThe bet and thus to
                    reed I nyl not spare
CULFf16.Note: Signed by scribe? ‘Amen Quod W. Caluerley’ (f. 42v).
CULFf16.Attributed Title:
Chaucers Parliament of Birds (added by later hand, f. 29); Explicit
                        Parliamente Amen Quod W Caluerley (by scribe, f.
                    42v)

CULHh412.First Lines:
The lyfe so short the craft so long to lerneThe assay so hard so
                    sharp the conqueryng…
CULHh412.Last Lines:
…The I thrustell old and the frosty feldfareWhat shuld I say
                    of fowlys eny kynnd…

CamMagPep2006.First Lines:
[t]he lif so short the craft so long to lurneThe assay so harde so
                    sharpe the conqueryng…
CamMagPep2006.Last Lines:
…And whann this werk is brought to an endeTo euery fowle
                    nature yaf his make…

            1985.

CamTCC599.First Lines:
so short þe lyfe þe craft so long to lerneThe assay so
                    hard so sharpe the conqueryngThe dredeful ioy all wey that fleeth so
                    yerneAll thys mene I be loue that my felyng…
CamTCC599.Last Lines:
…That I shall fynde somthyng for to fareThe bet and thus to
                    rede I wyll nat spareMaster Geffray Chausers that now lyth in graueThe
                    nobyll Rethoricioun and poet of gret bretayneThat worthy was the lawrer of
                    poetry haueffor thys hys labour and the palme atteyne
CamTCC599.Note: With four-line tribute to Chaucer at end.
CamTCC599.Attributed Author: by Chaucer (added by lated hand, ff. 17, 25)
CamTCC599.Attributed Title:
here foloweth the parlement of Burdes reducyd to loue et cetera (f.
                    17)
CamTCC599.Facsimiles:
Fletcher,  Bradford Y. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Trinity R.3.19. A Facsimile.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, 1987. 

Digital Facsimile of Trinity College Cambridge MS R.3.19.
         https://mss-cat.trin.cam.ac.uk/Manuscript/R.3.19.

BLHar7333.First Lines:
THe lyff so schort the crafte so longe to lerneþe assay so
                    hard so scharpe þe conquerynge…
BLHar7333.Last Lines:
The wordes were suche as yee may here fyndeThe next vers as I now
                    have in mynde

Longleat258.First Lines:
[T]he lif so short the craft so long to lereThe assay so herde so
                    sharpe the conqueryng…
Longleat258.Last Lines:
…That I shal mete sume thing for to fareThe bette and thus to
                    Rede I wol not spare
Longleat258.Attributed Title: Here endith the Parlement of foules (f. 101)
